snippet: Scientists say the rapid melting of the Quelccaya ice cap, the world’s largest tropical ice sheet, is the latest sign of global warming.
abstract: Study published in journal Science reports that glacial ice in Peruvian Andes that took at least 1,600 years to form has melted in just 25 years, latest indication that spike in global temperatures has thrown natural world out of balance; researchers used radioactive carbon dating of plants uncovered by melting to make determination.
lead_paragraph: Scientists say the rapid melting of the Quelccaya ice cap, the world’s largest tropical ice sheet, is the latest sign of global warming.

headline.seo: Ice That Took 1,600 Years to Form in Peru’s Andes Melted in Only 25, Scientists Say
headline.main: In Sign of Warming, 1,600 Years of Ice in  Andes Melted in 25 Years
headline.print_headline: In Sign of Global Warming, 1,600 Years of Ice in Peru’s Andes Melted in 25 Years
